The honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore), in his contribution tonight, related this decision to the elections in the Northern Territory. That is a somewhat cynical view. It should be noted that of the 24 safe anchorages referred to in the decision announced by the Minister for Industry and Commerce only eight are located in the Northern Territory. The Press release from the Minister for Industry and Commerce in which the decision of the Government was announced stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the extension was to enable a full review of the scheme to take place.
He said the Government remained concerned at abuses which had forced the Government, in the Budget, to tighten up the system.
This extension was not in any way related to the Northern Territory elections. It was made for the reasons stated by the Minister at the time. Further, the Minister's Press release indicated:

. . . one of the reasons for the extension had been the effect of the change on fishermen who had been greatly affected by the downturn in prawn prices. It would also give the Government, in consultation with the fishing industry and, if necessary, the Queensland Government, time to implement a system which would not be susceptible to abuse.
I think it is necessary to indicate the reasons for those changes. The decision was not related to the matter raised by the honourable member for Ryan.

The honourable member for Indi (Mr Ewen Cameron), the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew), the honourable member for Riverina (Mr Hicks) and the honourable member for Paterson (Mr O'Keefe) ranged across various matters related to the legislation before the House. The honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) raised matters which in no way relate to what is before us tonight .

The excise on fortified spirit and the related measures are budgetary measures. The purpose of the reintroduction of the excise was to lessen excise avoidance possibilities, simplify administration and yield revenue. Members of the industry directly involved in the production of fortified wine made representations to the Government to the effect that the excise rate imposed and its method of imposition would cause serious disruption to the industry. As a result of those discussions and representations made by those people, for whom concern was genuinely expressed by honourable members tonight, the Government decided to reduce the excise to $1.50 per litre without changing the method of imposition originally announced. Alternative methods of collection of the excise , canvassed in discussions with the industry, were found to involve considerable administrative problems. That was a matter adverted to by the honourable member for Riverina. An administrative problem is involved in the alternative method of collection. That is why the Government found it necessary to impose the excise at the time of production.

Other matters referred to included the diesel fuel rebate scheme. That, it was said, again by some honourable members opposite, was some sort of an attack on the rural community. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) announced in his Budget Speech that the amount of rebate payable would be fixed at 7.155c per litre, that the increase in the excise on diesel fuel to 9.027c per litre would mean that, after receiving the rebate, eligible users would pay a net 1.872c per litre. This duty now equates with the rate of duty applying to fuel oil, heating oil, and power and lighting kerosenes. The same situation applies to all such increases. Primary producers have retained the rebate. Listening to honourable members opposite speaking tonight, one would think that the rebate had not been retained . In fact, the rebate still applies. Their argument was about paying any excise at all. No consideration was given in their speeches to diesel fuel used in industries which receive no rebate.

The honourable member for Riverina referred to the aviation fuel increases of 2c per litre. It should be noted by the House that during 1983-84 the rate of excise on avgas and avtur was increased by 2c a litre from 1 July in lieu of an increase in air navigation charges. This will ameliorate the sharp deterioration in the rate of recovery of costs incurred by the Government in the provision of aviation services.

The honourable member for Paterson addressed his remarks to the petroleum products freight subsidy scheme, amongst other things. I think it is necessary to point out some facts about that matter to enlighten the honourable member for Paterson on the history relating to it. The petroleum products freight subsidy scheme was first introduced in 1965 and reintroduced in 1978 to assist country consumers of certain petroleum products by subsidising the transport costs of those products. Over the years the scheme has become more complex, more difficult to administer and, as a consequence, more open to abuse. For this reason the previous Government-that is, the Fraser Government-instituted a review of the scheme. On the basis of that review this Government has decided to amend the scheme. As I stressed in my second reading speech, the Government is not seeking to reduce the benefits of the scheme. Rather, it is improving its administration and limiting the scope for abuse. The amendments are estimated to save about only $2m in 1983-84 or $4m in a full year. The scheme will still cost the Government over $100m a year.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Uren) proposed:

That, in accordance with section 5 of the Parliament Act 1974, the House of Representatives approves the following proposals contained in the reports of the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory and the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House presented to the House on 22 September 1983 and 11 October 1983, respectively, namely: Commonwealth Avenue and Kings Avenue extension to the new Parliament House and the construction of pier protection under Commonwealth Avenue Bridge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The motion has the support of the Opposition. The Commonwealth Avenue bridge extension, in particular, is not without some element of controversy because of the intrusive nature of its design. The Minister for Territories and Local Government (Mr Uren) has personally taken an interest in this matter. I know members of the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House as well as members of the Joint Standing Committee on the Australian Capital Territory were very concerned that the design of that bridge should be less intrusive than was previously proposed. Our acceptance of this motion is, of course, in the expectation that the design will be less intrusive. The construction of the pier protection under Commonwealth Avenue bridge is very important. In the evidence given to the Committee on the new Parliament House it was quite clear that the bridge could be at risk if a very large motor vehicle hit the piers and brought it down. I regard that as a very important matter. The Minister and I are both aware of an incident in Sydney which led to very considerable concern about bridge designs. For that reason there is some urgency attaching to the work on Commonwealth Avenue bridge. It has the full support of the Opposition.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 18 May 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: Will the Attorney-General bring up to date the information given in answer to my question No. 241, parts (2) and (4), (Hansard, 12 April 1973, page 1461), concerning the authorisation of telephone tappings currently and during the last 10 years.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: I am advised that the reply to Dr Klugman in April 1973 was given by the then Attorney-General on the basis that it was appropriate to show publicly the general extent to which the provisions of the Act had been used, but that there would be no policy of automatically stating the number of current authorisations whenever asked.

In accordance with this approach, I advise that the average number of authorisations per year ending 31 March for the ten years from 1974 to 1983 was 85.6. This compares with an average of 90.9 per annum in the ten years from 1964 to 1973. It should be appreciated that a high proportion of the authorisations in any year represent renewals of warrants previously authorised.
The number of warrants presently authorised is of an order of magnitude consistent with the annual averages cited.

The Government will give further consideration to the detailed information it may be appropriate to make publicly available in the light of the recommendations, when received, of the Hope Royal Commission on Australia's Security and Intelligence Agencies.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Fisher Mr P.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, upon notice, on 22 September 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will established voluntary organisations, such as the Sports Medicine Foundation, receive the same percentage level of assistance they have received in past years following the establishment of the Sports Commission.
(2) Is a National Sports Research Institute planned.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) As the honourable member would be aware, an Interim Committee has been formed to advise the Government on the establishment of an Australian Sports Commission. It is envisaged that, in its report, the Interim Committee will examine the possible role of the Commission in establishing guidelines for the allocation of funds for sport and recreation. It is not possible at this stage to provide any guarantees that the current distribution of funds between sporting bodies will necessarily be maintained. However, I am confident that, due to the substantial increase in funds allocated for sport in the Budget, sporting bodies will generally be better off than they have been. The honourable member may be aware that this year the Australian Sports Medicine Federation has been granted an increased allocation of $50,000 compared with $31,500 in 1982-83 .

(2) At this stage there are no specific plans to establish a National Sports Research Institute. The Government is aware of the importance of co-ordinating the sports research effort in Australia. To this end, in 1982-83, it commenced assistance for a Sports Research Co-ordinator located with the Confederation of Australian Sport. The honourable member will also be aware that the Australian Institute of Sport has an important sports research function. I would expect that the report of the Interim Committee for the Australian Sports Commission will examine the potential role of the Commission in developing a co-ordinated approach to sports research in Australia.
